The wishes I originally sought have now all been destroyed, how can I rise up?

At that time, King SarvÄrthasiddha immediately gave rise to a compassionate mind and had this thought:

The poor ascetic's wishes have not been fulfilled, just like a hungry ghost who sees clear water from afar but cannot obtain it when it arrives, becoming disheartened and collapsing on the ground. This brÄhmaá¹‡a is also like this.

The brÄhmaá¹‡a asked the king:

The king then replied:
I have no money or property, but I have a skillful means that can enable you to obtain precious treasures.
The brÄhman said:
What is the skillful means?
The king further replied:
I previously heard the words of that enemy who resides in my country, and he has already proclaimed in the great assembly:
'If there is anyone who can obtain King SarvÄrthasiddha, whether by killing him, capturing him, or bringing him, I will heavily reward him according to his needs.'
I have never instructed people to engage in evil dharmas since ancient times, and therefore I will not allow you to cut off my head, but only bind me with ropes and send me to that king.
Why is it so?
Apart from the body, there is no other money or property.

Daoists, just observe, if my body were to die here, the corpse would be abandoned in the wilderness, no different from grass and trees. Although birds and beasts might come to eat it, what benefit would there be?

You are now the unsurpassed tamer, the parents of sentient beings, skillfully loving and protecting, the great place of refuge, able to extinguish all the fears of innumerable sentient beings. How can I destroy the true Dharma, bind your body, and send you to an enemy king?

If I were to accept them, my hands would fall to the ground;
